Reviews.Title: “Honeymoon in Rome!”
Reviews.Author: marycorrigan
Reviews.Content: It has been some time since I was here but I still remember the welcoming feeling that my then new husband and I felt when we stayed here for our honeymoon. So glad to see the sisters still are still providing such gracious hospitality. It is the perfect location in the heart of the city. Near Campo de Fiori and within walking distance of the Vatican. A perfect place to relax at the end of a busy travel day.

Reviews.Title: “Amazing location”
Reviews.Author: HelmutSchnitzel
Reviews.Content: We stayed here for 3 nights in February. The location can not be beat, steps off Campo de Fiori but worlds away in terms of noise and crowds. The roof deck has a spectacular view of city, I highly recommend going up there. All the sisters were very helpful and it seemed like they all spoke English. The convent was recommended to us by a friend who frequents Rome and we read about it in Rick Steves. I should note that none of the rooms have a bed for two, at best its two singles pushed together. The centralized location without being part of the tourist crowd was by far the best part of Casa di Santa Brigida.

Reviews.Title: “elegant convent in great location”
Reviews.Author: travelover11
Reviews.Content: This was recommended to me by a cousin who lives in Rome. I was expecting a simple place, nothing special, but safe for a solo traveler. I was surprised in many ways. The common areas in this convent are really beautiful, even the areas around the elevators are simple but so well done. My room was large and comfortable with antique furniture and a great view of the piazza. ( which did allow for some noise at night) The roof deck is incredible. I have never stayed ANYWHERE that was so clean. Honestly, I think you could eat off of the floors. The roof deck is beautiful. The breakfast was just okay, but adequate.

Reviews.Title: “Good location; an experience”
Reviews.Author: groovin087
Reviews.Content: You are safe here. It was a memorable experience staying at Santa Brigita in a good location. The garden top was beautiful and a must see, but I did have to make arrangments in advance to go there at dawn. Sister corrected my Italian, which I appreciated and made me smile - just like my Catholic School days. I went to Mass in the beautiful chapel. Lovely place. We were not in the convent most of the time, but you do feel a bit confined; (like you are in a convent)! I guess that's to be expected. It is exciting when you think that you are staying in a building from the 13 century where St. Bridget lived. Plan ahead to book a room, see St. Bridget's room, go on the beautiful rooftop, go to Mass with the nuns if you are so inclined.

Reviews.Title: “Peaceful refuge in Rome”
Reviews.Author: twee2822
Reviews.Content: This convent was a god-send in Rome. It is in an extrememly convenient location. I walked everywhere. The convent is on the beautiful Piazza Farnese which is right up against the Campo Di'Fiori with its beautiful flower market. Every night I did the "night walk" from the Campo Di'Fiori to the Piazza Navona, to the Pantheon, to the Trevi Fountain to the Spanish Steps. It was so beautiful and romantic! The sisters are reserved, but very nice. I tried to be very respectful and friendly, and they were always very helpful in answering any questions I had. If you want internet, make sure to request it before you are given your room. Some rooms do not have internet access. The access is provided through an ethernet cable. My room also had excellent A/C. The roof-top is beautiful and a nice place to relax. The convent also has nice sitting rooms, a library and a tv room.

Reviews.Title: “A home away from home and a quiet retreat it the midst of the city”
Reviews.Author: drshields
Reviews.Content: This was our 4th time staying at this hotel. Though we have been to Rome almost ever other year since 97, once we found this, we book it each time. For us it is more home away from home and a guest house than a hotel. The sisters are quiet because they are semi cloistered, so service is gentle. No need for tips just offer a gracious thank you or not, yet you become one remembered in their daily prayers. Their roof top terrace is lovely with a view of the city, and great place for a hot evening away from it all. The library is gorgeous. Tiny nooks containing antiques are available for sitting. The public is invited to attend prayer services, and one can request a tour of the private rooms of Saint Brigitta. The location is perfect for day sightseeing and evening strolling, close to everything. A few evenings can be a bit noisy in the summer since it is next to the French Embassy and right on the piazza Farnese where groups gather for events, which many of them were interesting to watch from the roof. But that is Rome. I plan to be there again in October if they have room. I can agree the price per room seems high if it is compared to a guest house run by a religious order, but compared to a hotel it is a bargain. And the location can't be beat for the price, not to mention the safe area if traveling alone.

Reviews.Title: “Would Stay Here Again”
Reviews.Author: jj1919
Reviews.Content: My sister, daughter and I stayed in two rooms for three nights. Lovely refuge in the middle of the busy city. This was a great location within walking distance to every place we wanted to go but we also bused quite a bit because they are so easily available. Room was immaculate and while the bathroom was small it also was very clean and perfectly functional. Nuns were very hospitable and available as needed to answer questions, arrange taxi, pay bill, etc. We had an AC in both of our rooms which was also much appreciated.

Reviews.Title: “Charming, quaint, excellent location.”
Reviews.Author: Marcie61
Reviews.Content: Pros: convenient location, catch #116 electric bus at Cancelleria to Villa Borghese Gardens (Galleria Borghese), walking distance to Via Vittorio Emanuele where you can catch buses to Termini station, Colosseum, Vatican etc., Just be careful which side of the street you are on or you could be heading in the wrong direction. You can buy bus tickets for a euro at the Tabachi shop on Monserrato or the newspaper stand with the green awning in the piazza Farnese. 15 euros plus 1 euro for each suitcase for taxi to Termini station. Steps from the Campo di Fiori which has a morning market. Surrounded by restaurants and other shops (delicatessen, bakery). Convenient pizza by the slice place Pizzeria al tagio via del pellegrino. Despar (convenience store) on Via del Pettinari, 70. Convent is kitty corner to the Palazzo Farnese which is the French Embassy. Apparently you can visit it if you make an appointment in advance. Lovely breakfast at the convent. Meat, cheese, egg, yogurt, bread, fruit, juice, great coffee! Lovely full course dinners with appetizers and dessert. You can get a wine keep. We ordered wine at our dinner and they brought out the same bottle again for our next dinner. We had a huge room with a huge bathroom with tub and shower overlooking the piazza. There was even a sitting room with a television. Lots of tile, old squeaky furniture and doors. They charge you extra if you pay by credit card. We paid by bank draft. Cons: no internet, no hair conditioner, no dryer, no air conditioning (but was cool enough); but if you left the windows open, the noise from the piazza or the seagulls might bother you

Reviews.Title: “Quiet, clean, somber but well located place to stay”
Reviews.Author: birder-snorkeler
Reviews.Content: We stayed at Casa di Santa Bridida just off the Campo Fiori for a week in May '11 and were delighted with it. A great location , you can walk to P. Navona, Pantheon, Fountain of Trevi, & most of central Rome sights from here. Run by Swedish nuns, the rooms are simple, clean, have everything you need. There is no curfew and breakfast is included. One may sign up for inexpensive but tasty meals here if you wish at a set hour. The place is quiet and there is usually a nun who speaks english at the desk but of course features like concierge, restaurant, night club, bar are missing. Frequented by many return visitors. We would stay here again.

Reviews.Title: “Best treat i ever gave myself.”
Reviews.Author: delialuci
Reviews.Content: Stayed for 1 week for beatification of JPII. Never travelled alone to a foreign country before, but have been to Rome several times with husband and 5 children and stayed in apartments. What a wonderful experience! Beautiful convent, lovely nuns...nothing was too much trouble...met some very interesting people staying there from other countries. Location perfect, facilities excellent, breakfast was typical Roman but didn't try other meals because I was out of there most of the day....can't wait to go back again...a bit expensive on the scale of things compared to other convents, but I'm planning my next trip...a taste of heaven as far as I'm concerned.

Reviews.Title: “Perfect place to stay in Rome”
Reviews.Author: weather1
Reviews.Content: Stayed here on a recent 3 night stay in Rome at the recommendation of Rick Steve's guidebook. He was very accurate in his description. While staying in this convent, you would never guess that you were in the middle of an incredibly busy, chaotic and noisy city. The convent itself was beautifully decorated, cool and quiet. The room was beautiful, clean and comfortable. Beds (two singles, no doubles or queens here) were very comfortable. Shower was a little small, so if you are a big person this could be an issue. Very quiet, except for Friday night when Rome was in full party mode, so slept very well in general. Breakfasts were delicious (fresh fruit, cereal, juice, coffee, meats and cheese) and the sisters were very kind and helpful. Rooftop terrace overlooking Piazza Farnese and the city of Rome was great for relaxing before dinner. Although, it may sound strange, one of the best things about staying here was the feeling of safety provided in a not always so safe city. Location may have been the best part of staying here. On beautiful Piazza Farnese and right next to Campo di Fiori with its plentiful restaurants, fresh fruit and vegetable markets during the day and active nightlife. Also, within walking distance of all of the tourist attractions including ancient Rome and the Vatican. Would highly recommend this hotel and would stay here again if returning to Rome.

Reviews.Title: “The Good, The Bad and the Ugly”
Reviews.Author: zoe17
Reviews.Content: Overall, the hotel was OK. Because the hotel is run by nuns, at times their attitudes become an issue. It also meant that their schedule dictated when you could do things like settle the bill and have breakfast (8 am - 9 am, unless special arrangements are made). I have travelled primarily as a single since 2006, and the single room (NUMBER 23) they put me in initially measured less than 11 feet by 11 feet, inlcuding the microscopic bathroom. The twin bed was the worst I'd slept in since 1974, It had a slope and a trough, which made sleeping difficult. The shower curtain was a joke, and toilet paper and a lot of other stuff got wet from the morning shower. They put me into number 19 the next day, and the room and bathroom were much larger and better organized. Be aware that the rooms don't have TV, and the TV in the lounge doesn't get any English-speaking channels. The hotel also does not provide room safes, and you must ask to use a hair dryer or get more soap or shampoo. Breakfast is adequate - coffee, rolls, jam, cold cuts, yogurt. The hotel is well situated right off the Piazza Farnese and a couple blocks from the Campo de' Fiori. The Campo is a lot of fun, with a ton of pricey restaurants nearby. (If you want reasonably priced food, go to 33 Gubbonari to Voglia Pizzaria Spaghetteria.) The hotel's site and cleanliness enable it to get very high room rates. Save you initial emails from the hotel, as they raised the rates 10 euros/night per room between when we reserved and when we checked out. There was a lot of noise outside the hotel during the weekend. The hotel is pretty with a lot of period furniture and antiques. This just doesn't help at all in the comfort of the rooms. The roof top terrace is pleasant in the evening.

Reviews.Title: “Lost its charm”
Reviews.Author: Gerri777
Reviews.Content: We had been staying in the Casa a number of times, first time in 1972. We always tried to get a reservation when we were in Rome. It was charming. Last time we went, everything was still the same - beds and all. We were stuck in a small room with no shower. Couldn't work the hand held one and showered the bathroom. We asked to be moved to a room with a shower, and they begrudgingly moved us - to an even smaller room that hardly fit our 2 suitcases. There was a little portable shower in the corner of the bathroom, but it was so small you couldn't bend down to pick up the soap. The nuns were quite upset with us for wanting to use their computer to check our Email (we had urgent business coming in each day). They ended up charging us quite a bit for its usage as we checked out. The cost of the room was on a par with some 4 star hotels - out of line for what you get. All in all it lost its charm for us.

Reviews.Title: “Great location. Very kind nuns.”
Reviews.Author: spindrifter
Reviews.Content: Beautiful convent. I stayed 4 nights in November and had the best experience. The convent is immaculately clean. The location can't be beat and was walking distance to all the major sites with many good restaurants nearby. The nuns were incredibly kind. Would stay here again if I go back to Rome.

Reviews.Title: “Warm Hospitality, Great Location, Unique Experience- A Convent!”
Reviews.Author: mgbrider
Reviews.Content: We stayed 3 nights during our recent trip to Rome and chose a Convent for the unique experience. Since we are Catholic and have priests in the family, we felt at home. The room was lovely, overlooking the Piazza Farnese, close to the Campo di Fiori. It was very comfortable (twin beds). Sr Gertrude went above and beyond to make our stay the best, arranging for us to have an early breakfast to accommodate our travel plans. She gave us a little tour of the Chiesa Santa Brigida, including the rooms the Saint occupied and some of their relics. It was really inspiring. When the laundry forgot my husband's pants, she made sure they got sent to us! We hope to go back some day!

Reviews.Title: “If you can get in, this is the only place to stay while in Rome”
Reviews.Author: NJMaggie
Reviews.Content: My wife and I have been in the travel business for over thirty years. I traveled with my daughter and teenage grandson to Rome and stayed at the Casa di Santa Brigida five days. What can I say? It is the very best deal going. The place is run by a group of lovely nuns. As expected, the place is spotless. It is in an old Palazzo located on the Piazza Farnese directly adjacent to the French Embassy. The location cannot be beat: walk to Campo dei Fiori, Piazza Navona, Vatican, Trastevere, Pantheon, etc. Breakfast was perfect and lunch and dinner is possible, though we did not do that. Sisters are extremely helpful and knowledgeable of Rome. You can access them by going to the order's home page at /www.brigidine.org and click on accommodations. Note that they also have other accommodations in about fifteen other countries. This is a great place to stay in Rome, especially for the price and the location. How often do you get the chance to stay right on the Piazza Farnese in the heart of Rome

Reviews.Title: “These nuns are so nice!”
Reviews.Author: Zafraan
Reviews.Content: Also try their Convent in Farfa, about 60 km north of Rome - that is even more some of an experience. And the countryside is very nice there.

Reviews.Title: “Location, Location, Location”
Reviews.Author: creampuff09
Reviews.Content: A welcoming, wonderful way to experience Rome. Close to Piazza Farnese, a hot spot amoung tourists and locals with a fun market and great food. This convent is run by kind, quiet nuns which is a relief from the hustle and bustle known as Rome. While this is not a place for those that enjoy getting crazy in their room, it is perfect for the rest of us who hit the city first thing in the morning and crash by Midnight. My favorite is the beautiful roof top terrace. The perfect place to enjoy a glass of wine or dessert! A Rick Steves recommendation - right on!

Reviews.Title: “Perfect for single woman travelling alone!”
Reviews.Author: chirpup
Reviews.Content: I spent 3 weeks at Santa Brigida in a single room. Clean, spare, and with a hard bed, but a clean private bathroom, telephone and a/c. Breakfast was adequate, and dinners (request at breakfast) simple, multi-course, tasty and - wine served at request (you get your own bottle!) Library with some books in English. Big bonus? - the rooftop terrace! Nice to sit at close of day, planning the next day's itinerary, with the domes of Rome all around, roses at your feet, and the bells chiming! Even bigger bonus - I got sick (on street food) one night, and was really under par by morning. When I didn't show for breakfast, the nuns called my room to see if I was OK. I wasn't, so up they came, took a look, and flew to get me dry toast and tea, an anti-nausea/diarrhea pill, and a huge bottle of mineral water. "Swallow this, eat that, drink this" I was told, and I did. Everything started to clear up within an hour, but I stayed in all day - and the nuns came up at noon, at 3pm and at dinner time, bringing tea and toast and chicken soup and TLC! I was almost inn tears at their kindness! And Oh yes - the Casa has a HISTORY (ask the nuns), and has LOCATION< LOCATION< LOCATION! Even on my own I felt perfectly comfortable going out in the evening the short block to the Campo de Fiori, sitting outside a wine bar, and watching the people and the street entertainers. (There are also a couple of gelaterias on site.) Perfecto! Would I stay there again? You betcha. Yes, it was not inexpensive - but - for an older woman travelling alone - GREAT.

Reviews.Title: “Divine!”
Reviews.Author: LynJimmy
Reviews.Content: What a divine experience staying with the Sisters of St. Brigid in Rome, Italy. My husband and I spent a good amount of time deciding where to stay during our visit to Rome in June 2008 and we have discovered a little piece of heaven. The convent is meticuously clean, serene, beautifully detailed with marble floors and wrought iron hand rails, comfortable rooms with private baths (an important amenity for us), luxurious bed linens and large bath towels. It is simple is its traditional yet elegant decor which gives it a wonderfully peaceful ambiance after the intensity of sightseeinging in Rome. There is no curfew. The breakfast is a light start with bread, cured meats, cheese, yogurt and fruit. A beautiful rooftop terrace is a perfect place for relaxation before an evening out. The Sisters were friendly and greeted us warmly. They offered us maps and a bottle of cold water upon our arrival. They move quietly about the place giving weary travelers a sense of security. The Casa Di' Santa Brigida is also perfectly located on the peaceful Piazza Farnese which is one block from the Campo di' Fiori - a piazza famous for its open air produce market during the day and lively outdoor dining at night. There are two fountains on the Piazza Farnese which add to its charm. It is an easy walk to Largo Argentina - the main hub for buses - and an easy walk to Piazza Navona, Pantheon, Vatican, and the Trastevere neighborhood. From here, we walked all around Rome, took a couple of cab rides to far out places like the Galleria Borghese. My husband feel in love with Bar Farnese which served up the most delicious espresso and capuccino from early in the morning until mid-day. For us, there was nothing about these accommodations that disappointed. But if you are looking for over-the-top extravagance or self-indulgent services or a party atmosphere this is not the place for you. However, if you need a peaceful, clean, private, serene, charming place to rest during your travels, the Casa di' Santa Brigida is a wonderful experience.

Reviews.Title: “Great location, terrible place”
Reviews.Author: orangeguy
Reviews.Content: We booked our stay based largely on positive Trip Advisor feedback and Rick Steve's description of a place where weary travelers will feel as if they have died and gone to heaven. If you haven't read it, the description in Bed and Blessings Italy: A Guide to Convents and Monasteries Available for Overnight Lodging is far more accurate. They describe the place as simple wth sub-par staff. On a positive note, the location is outstanding and a very convenient area from which to base your Rome stay. It's a close walk to all the major sights. In addition, the location on Piazza Farnese gives it a certain charm. The Room: We stayed in room #29, which is one of their "family" rooms (we wanted a double). The room was reasonably clean but very simple. The floors were cold and hard, not wood like in other rooms. The bathroom looked reasonably clean, but the toilet smelled slightly of urine. Be prepared for thin, air dried towels (stiff and rough). Our room was right on the Piazza, which was interesting because with the windows closed the room was very hot and stuffy. So, we decided to leave the windows open, which made it feel like you were sleeping in the middle of the road - noisy all night long. The Service: While I might be able to overlook the quality of the room, the service was really the icing on the cake. It all started out badly and didn't get any better. We went to the address on the reservation e-mail. However, what they didn't say was that the address on the e-mail is for the church/convent side. So, we were immediately scolded for going to the wrong door. Not exactly welcoming. We decided to try to sleep in on our first day since we were both jet lagged. We were still in our room when they came by to clean it, so we asked that they come back in about 1 hour to 30 minutes. We were told that would not be possible since that would go into their lunch time. So, forget it , we didn't get our room cleaned on the first day. Not a major deal, but a little annoying given the prices they charge. The real topper was when we were asking for advice on where to go and what to see. Our stay in Rome gave us two full days on 5/16/07 and 5/17/07, staying with the nuns the nights of 5/15-5/17. This was not the first stop on our trip, so we were kind of out of it. Anyway, it turns out that 5/17/07 was a religous holiday, the Feast of the Ascension, and the Vatican Museum would be closed. While we probably should have known this, it would have been nice for the sisters to point out that if we were planning to got the Vatican to go on 5/16 and not 5/17. Advice I would certainly expect from a tourist hotel's staff. So, we managed to miss the Vatican Museum (Sistine Chapel) this trip. Finally, we were departing Rome early morning 5/18. Since we were catching a train, we were told we didn't need to book a cab the night before, but that they would call us one in the morning. They would certainly be there at 7:00 am. Well, we went to leave at 7:00 and there wasn't a nun in sight. We ended up walking out to the street and hailing a cab there. Final thoughts: Okay, I'll admit that this probably sounds a bit nitpicky and that I should have a different standard for this place since it is a convent. Well, I would agree with that if this they charged discount prices. At 190 euros + an additional 5% fee for credit card payment, one should be able to expect a little more than a room with a bed. Next time I'll be staying at a hotel in the same area.

Reviews.Title: “Superb Historic Convent”
Reviews.Author: Enis
Reviews.Content: Returned last week in September, having spent 6 nights at the Casa di Santa Brigida, Piazza Farnese. We paid 110 euros for a single room, doubles are 170 euros including breakfast. There are no added taxes. When one considers the high prices for a room on the Upper East Side of Manhattan or our downtown San Francisco, this is a bargain. The convent has 20 rooms. They have an excellent TV room on the third floor, a library, nice sitting rooms and a roof terrace with tables and chairs for reading. The building is 15th century and in the heart of the historic center. It is five minutes away from a foot bridge crossing the Tiber River into the old quarter of Trastavere. On the way, you pass the Pontifical College. It is also 8 minutes away from the Piazza Navona with its Bernini Fountain. We were steps away from Campo di Fiori (Rick Steve's favorite square in Rome). Every day we walked to the Blue Ice Gelato Store where people were lined up. All flavors are outstanding. A bench is provided outside where one can sit and watch the world go by. Catching the bus on Victor Emmanuel to the Vatican was effortless--- the bus runs every 7 minutes. Many of the Sisters speak English--several are from India. They were most gracious and accommodating--particularly on giving directions and short cuts to historic places. We were given a key to the front door. It is always locked, making one feel that they were living in their own mansion. There is no curfew. They have some beautiful antiques and their church (through a small courtyard) has a marble tomb, a magnificent fresco, mosaics and beautiful paintings. We will definitely return to this peaceful setting and genuine hospitality.

Reviews.Title: “Serenity in Central Rome”
Reviews.Author: PolkaDot53
Reviews.Content: As we are not accustomed to long walks and the cold of winter, we chose to stay at the Casa di Santa Brigida last January owing to its central location. It was a wise decision and although their accommodations are priced higher than other convents, one cannot get the same value-for-money deal elsewhere in central Rome. Our room was spotlessly clean, the beds were firm, and we enjoyed the delicious home-cooked food of the sisters. Although our room looked out to Piazza Farnese, we were not the least disturbed by any noise. They have no curfew, so we felt quite comfortable about doing a day trip to Siena. The nuns are able to provide special passes for the papal audience at no cost. I guess what we appreciated most is the serenity of the place which provided the best ambience for our Christian pilgrimage. There are daily Masses every morning except Wednesdays (when Mass is at sunset). Upon check-out, we immediately booked rooms for a family vacation 10 months ahead, but guess what, they are almost booked out already.

Reviews.Title: “How often do you get to stay in a convent?”
Reviews.Author: KiNdReDSpRiT
Reviews.Content: Our stay at Casa Di Santa Brigida was a pleasant surprise. We were't sure what to expect based on some of the earlier reviews, but we found the sisters to be warm, friendly and charming. We had no problems during our stay. The location is great because the convent is right next to the popular Campo De Fiori and Piazza Navona, however, the convent itself is in Piazza Farnese, which is nice and quiet. We were able to walk to most of the major sites, but did take the occasional taxi because Rome is so big. Breakfasts were good and the rooms were small but immaculate. We're a married couple and we pushed our twin beds together, so the sleeping arrangement wasn't bad. The rooftop terrace is lovely. One word of caution, making the reservation was much harder than it needed to be. The nuns don't take credit card reservations; instead, they require you to send a personal check for deposit. They weren't clear about this until about the fourth email. Their lack of timeliness in responding to our emails left us worrying about whether our reservation was confirmed.

Reviews.Title: “Great location, nice nuns, some quibbles”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: The location, in Piazza Farnese, is great -- near Camp de Fiore, near Trastevere, close enough to the Vatican and all the big tourist sites. The breakfasts are pretty austere, but Americans pig out too much at breakfast anyway, and since Italy is a country for elaborate lunches and dinners, an austere breakfast is a good check. The rooms come with multi-layered windows and shutters that completely block out the sound of the street below, and the nuns are great -- very idiosyncratic, witty, and they speak very little English -- a plus, if you're trying to practice your Italian. On the downside, the air-conditioning is very weak, so if it's summer, the room will be only marginably comfortable. Also, the nuns know how cute they are, so look out for them. I paid my deposit on an agreed rate only to have them jack up the price when it was time to check out. Not wanting to get into a money dispute with a nun, I let that sneaky sister beat me out of almost 50 bucks. Beware.

Reviews.Title: “Home away from home”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: My first stay with the sisters was over 14 years ago. I then returned in August on 2002 with my fiance who had never traveled out of the US. (We were there to get married at my aunt's house in Tuscany). We are going back to Italy for our 2nd anniversary and of course, back to Rome. We would not consider staying anywhere else than with the sisters. We actually almost cancelled Rome as a stop because the sisters e-mailed us that they were booked on the dates that we wanted to stay in Rome. Several days later they e-mailed us back letting us know that they would be able to accomodate us. In 2002 they were nice enough to give us a tour of Santa Brigida's private living quarters and they have always been kind and helpful. The breakfast is simple but very typical of Italy - the best way to assure a great vacation is to keep an open mind and go with the flow. The rooms are simple but very clean. The greatest advantage of all is the location - it just simply cannot be beat.

Reviews.Title: “comfortable quiet and clean with great location”
Reviews.Author: crunkcar
Reviews.Content: My stay at Casa di Santa Brigida was wonderful. The room was quiet and spotlessly clean and the location was perfect. The Sisters were gracious and hospitable and the food was excellent. Breakfast is included in the basic rate. Lunch and dinner are EUR 30 extra per day and the food was excellent.... has to be the best meal value in Rome.

Reviews.Title: “Disappointed in this overpriced convent”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: My daughter and I stayed at Casa di Santa Brigida for four nights in July, 2004. On the plus side, the location was absolutely tops, on the quiet Piazza Farnesse, just steps from the wonderful Campo di Fiore and a few blocks from the even more wonderful Piazza Navona. We also were able to walk to St. Peter's without any trouble and also to the Forum and Colosseum, although those latter two are quite a walk, but doable. Also, the public rooms in the convent are lovely and there's a very nice rooftop terrace with chairs and a table. Now to the negatives. I guess the over $200 a night they charge is for the location, because the room, breakfast and helpfulness of the sisters left a lot to be desired. The beds in our room (#12) were so squeaky they woke us up at night when we shifted in our sleep. And the pillows were rock hard. Other than that, no complaints about the room other than it wasn't worth the price. Breakfast was disappointing. There was good American-style coffee and orange juice, but other than than, only a hard roll and a slice of meat and/or cheese. One day instead of the meat and cheese, we were served hard boiled eggs. Compared to our breakfasts in other Italian cities we visited, which were buffets including yogurt and fresh fruit and various types of breads, this one was certainly lacking. We had read in the book "Bed and Blessings" that the sisters at St. Bridget's were not particularly warm and we found that to be the case. I felt that I was bothering them if I asked for something. One day we wanted a little ice, and after being told we had to wait a few minutes while the sister at the desk finished something she was doing, we were told there was no ice after all, that the sisters had finished it all. We felt like we were tolerated visitors there instead of welcome guests like you would normally feel in a hotel. What irked me the most was the day we went to St. Peter's and one of the sisters at the convent told me I could wear a sleeveless shirt into the church. Well, we got there and of course I couldn't, so we had to leave the walking tour we were a part of and go back outside and scrounge around to find something to cover my shoulders. I ended up having to buy a scarf to cover myself up. We couldn't believe a nun could be that ill informed. So all in all, while the location is simply marvelous, next time we'll opt for a hotel nearby, of which there are several. The pricey Casa di Santa Brigida just isn't worth the money.
